title: Ticket #7038: Tool needed to examine SPOOL while job is idle.
description:
[GregT reports that] LIGO requests a tool to help inspect the checkpoint of a vanilla universe job while it is idle. UI/X questions abound.

See also #7003, part 3.
remarks:
2019-Jul-31 13:32:16 by pfc:
I upped the priority of this because it's a general usability issue for future vanilla-universe checkpointing users...

2019-Sep-04 13:28:08 by tlmiller:
First pass pushed to a branch. Needs a few fix-ups before being merged, even in its truncated form. (Mostly making it work on Windows and quoting the directory arguments properly.)

2019-Sep-04 14:07:53 by tlmiller:
Other potential extensions include:

  1. checking in with the schedd to see if the job ID in question exists,
  2. and a -quiet flag, in the unlikely event that this will be useful in scripts.

2019-Sep-11 13:58:38 by tlmiller:
Get a private beta to James Clark for testing (after writing up what it is he needs to test).

2019-Sep-12 16:10:09 by tlmiller:
The tool is (currently) called condor_evicted_files. 

Usage: condor_evicted_files [COMMAND] (clusterID.procID)+
Deal with evicted files.

With no COMMAND, assume DIR.  Otherwise:
	dir	Print the directory in which the files are stored.
	list	List the evicted files.
	get	Copy the evicted files to a subdirectory named after the job ID.

The tool presently has a number of limitations:

  1. It must be run the same machine as the job's schedd
  2. The schedd must NOT have ALTERNATE_JOB_SPOOL set
  3. You can't name the destination directory for the get command.

The tool also does not contact the schedd in question. This is good for some things (reduces load on the schedd, makes it safer to test), but it does mean that the tool by itself can't tell the difference between an invalid job ID and job that never had any checkpointed (or otherwise spooled) files.

I'm also just guessing about what might of interest/convenience to the user, so if you've got thoughts, please do share.
